byline.contributor: Alissa J. Rubin, Adam Nossiter and Lilia Blaise contributed reporting from Paris.

abstract: Authorities in Europe and United States struggle to identify potential homegrown terrorists and head off attacks before they occur, hobbled by limitations of hearsay and huge caseload; problem is exemplified by French attacker Larossi Abballa and Omar Mateen, perpetrator in Orlando massacre, who both exhibited radical tendencies but did not cross legal lines that would have decisively attracted authorities' notice.

headline.print_headline: Attacks Expose a Struggle  to Spot Future Terrorists
headline.main: How Do You Stop a Future Terrorist When the Only Evidence Is a Thought?

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
keywords.name: organizations

snippet: The authorities are trying to reckon with attackers whose names had surfaced in terrorism investigations but who had crossed no legal boundary.
lead_paragraph: The authorities are trying to reckon with attackers whose names had surfaced in terrorism investigations but who had crossed no legal boundary.
